Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Melatonin Regulation of Vocal Behavior
Award.AbstractNarration:
Circadian rhythms that approximate the 24 hr day-night cycle, synchronize animal behavior and physiology to cyclical changes in environmental cues, such as light, temperature, and the availability of mates. How biological rhythms are generated by hormonal, genetic, and neural mechanisms is of great scientific interest. The nocturnal hormone melatonin plays a central role in entraining daily activity to the day-night cycle. In many mammals, activity and mating occur at night so there is potential for melatonin to regulate important reproductive behaviors such as vocalizations used in courtship. This project will investigate circadian and melatonin regulation of daily rhythms in the vocal behavior of a nocturnally active and highly vocal fish, the plainfin midshipman (Porichthys notatus) by answering three questions: (1) Is the daily vocal rhythm under internal, circadian control? (2) Does melatonin stimulate nocturnal vocal behavior? (3) Does melatonin regulate gene expression underlying neural excitability in vocal brain regions? These studies will contribute to a comparative framework for predicting melatonin regulation of vocal behavior in other species, including birds and mammals that exhibit divergent daily activity patterns. More broadly, melatonin has been implicated in sleep, jetlag, autism and epilepsy, making basic research on how it affects social communication and neural excitability important and widely applicable.

This project will test the overall hypothesis that the midshipman's nocturnal courtship vocalization is under circadian control and stimulated by melatonin. Proposed studies will (1) record vocalizations from naturally behaving fish under constant external light conditions to test for an internally generated circadian vocal rhythm, (2) implant fish with melatonin to test for melatonin regulation of vocal behavior, and (3) seek a deeper understanding of how melatonin influences daily rhythms in vocal behavior by examining its regulation of neural excitability-related gene expression in a well-characterized vocal network. If the midshipman daily vocal rhythm is under endogenous circadian control, it is predicted that rhythms recorded under a normal light regime will persist under constant darkness with a period of ~24 hr. Additionally, if midshipman vocal behavior is dependent on melatonin action, it is predicted that vocalizations will be reduced or abolished under constant light, shown to abolish melatonin production, while exogenous melatonin replacement under light will rescue the occurrence of vocalizations. Finally, the researchers predict that melatonin increases the expression of previously identified candidate genes known to affect neural excitability. These genes encode three types of ion channels and exhibit increased expression in a hindbrain vocal nucleus collected during the summer night, a time of maximal natural vocal behavior. Given conserved functions of the candidate genes explored in this proposal, such mechanisms could provide the molecular basis for translating the nocturnal melatonin signal to increase or decrease neural excitability in nocturnal versus diurnal animals, respectively. This project will train current and new undergraduates of both genders from diverse backgrounds, including underrepresented minorities. The results will be disseminated in open-access peer-reviewed journals, popular articles via online platforms, at national and international conferences, and at local science outreach events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robust temporal rhythms in acoustic behaviors enhance sender-receiver coupling and, in turn, reproductive success in animals that depend on acoustic communication to attract mates. Courtship vocalizations in many species occur over predictable day-night cycles, including in a diversity of fish species. The nocturnal hormone melatonin is a major timekeeping mechanism and regulates circadian behaviors in vertebrate animals. Few studies, however, have examined either circadian or melatonin control of vocal behaviors, especially in nocturnal species as diurnal songbirds have been the predominant models for studying vocalization.

Utilizing continuous sound recordings, light cycle manipulations, and hormone implants, we demonstrated in a nocturnally breeding teleost fish, the plainfin midshipman (Porichthys notatus) that (1) courtship vocalization followed an internally-generated circadian rhythm under constant dark conditions, (2) increasing melatonin levels under inhibitory constant light conditions rescued courtship vocal activity as well as the duration of single calls, and (3) a melatonin receptor was highly expressed in evolutionarily conserved brain regions that are important for controlling reproductive and vocal behaviors in fishes, as well as in birds and mammals.

The results of our investigation are significant in several regards. First, although many fish species are vocal, our study is the first to demonstrate endogenous circadian control of overt daily rhythms as well as melatonin regulation of sound production. Second, the results reveal melatonin’s remarkable versatility as a circadian timing signal in distantly related vertebrate species, conveying the permissive time period for vocalization in an opposing manner to permit vocalization in nocturnal fish and suppress vocalization in diurnal birds. Third, melatonin surprisingly acts in a similar manner that lengthens the duration of single calls in both fish and birds, indicating an ability to pattern vocalization at the millisecond-minute timescale. Thus, while melatonin synchronizes activity patterns with environmental cues such as photoperiod, it can also sculpt the finer temporal patterning of individual behavioral events. Finally, melatonin receptor expression in both neuroendocrine and vocal patterning centers suggests that melatonin’s timescale-dependent effects on behavior are executed by discrete, evolutionarily conserved neural pathways. Although poorly studied outside of avian vocalizations, results in birds and now our results in fish suggest that melatonin control of vocalization over vastly different timescales is a trait shared by distantly related species of vertebrate animals.

In sum, our study uses a unique and charismatic model system, a vocal fish, to probe general biological phenomena: hormone control of social communication and the familiar sleep-wake cycle that governs the schedules of our daily lives. The discovery of a melatonin-sensitive circadian rhythm in fish will contribute to a broader understanding of hormone control of vocal communication across vertebrates. Furthermore, melatonin has been implicated in sleep, jetlag, autism, and epilepsy, making basic research on how it affects social communication and neural excitability important and widely applicable.

This project has given the Co-PI invaluable training in sound recording and analysis, as well as using the Python programming language for circadian data analysis and visualization. The Co-PI trained three female undergraduates on sound recording and analyses. One trainee was a McNair Scholar, and another will stay in the lab to complete an independent senior honors thesis, and will continue to use the equipment and analysis techniques developed under this funded project.
